metadata.title: Iron-based magnetic nanomaterials and their environmental applications

sections.text: KEYWORDS Iron-based magnetic nanomaterials; remediation; environmental analysis; nanoscale zero-valent iron; functionalized iron composites

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Since nanotechnology was first introduced, it has shown great promise to play a key role in various technological fields; nanomaterials are the cornerstone of this booming technology. As the nano indicates, nanomaterials are materials whose structural elements (for at least one dimension) have been engineered at the nanometer scale (1–100 nm),[1] conferring to them novel properties not present in their bulk constituents.[2] The uniqueness of these materials stems from their desirable mechanical, electrical, optical, catalytic, and photonic properties, and, of special note, their extremely high surface area. As a result of their special structures, small size effects, surface effects, quantum size effects, and macroscopic quantum tunneling effects emerge. Many nanomaterials possess superior catalytic, analytical, chemical, and environmentally protective capabilities, and take the forms of carbon nanotubes, TiO2 nanotube arrays, graphene, metal or metal oxide NPs, and novel organic/inorganic nanocomposites.[3–8]
Iron-based magnetic nanoparticles (IMNPs) belong to the zero-dimensional nanomaterial category. They are also described as a smart nanomaterials, because in addition to the general advantages they share with other NPs, such as good mechanical, electrical, optical, catalytic, and photonic properties, they also possess the additional useful feature of magnetism. When an external magnetic field is applied, they will rapidly cluster, a useful property for manipulation, separation, and regeneration.[9,10] However, before they can be used, several obstacles must be surmounted. Bare IMNPs, especially NZVIs, are unstable in air or moisture, oxidize easily, and readily aggregate due to their large surface area and high surface energy.[11,12] To overcome these obstacles, researchers are attempting to coat their surfaces with organic, inorganic, or doped hybrid polymers.
Up until now, many preparation methods for IMNPs and their multifunctional composites have been developed, such as chemical coprecipitation, sol-gel synthesis, thermal decomposition or reduction, microemulsion polymerization, hydrothermal synthesis, and others.[13,14] Over the past two decades, researchers have found that they must precisely control synthesis conditions and surface functionalization of IMNPs, because their ultimate surface characteristics govern their physicochemical properties, colloidal stability, biological behavior/fate, and magnetism.[15] IMNPs have been successfully applied in electronic, biomedical, pharmaceutical, cosmetic, energy, diagnostics, molecular biological, environmental, catalytic, and material applications fields.[10,15–18]
Environmental pollution occurs in various matrices such as air, water, and soils. Pollutants can have harmful effects on humans and animals, entering them via several routes: the food chain, inhalation, and acute or chronic skin contact. It is well known that pollution has become a serious global problem, and various governments and researchers are starting to seriously address this growing problem. Although nanomaterials have gained success in chemical, biological, biomedical, and material field applications, the application of these materials to the environmental field has only begun very recently. So far, IMNPs have exhibited great potential utility for trace pollutant analysis and remediation of a broad range of environmental pollutants. The combination of nanotechnology and environmental science has thus become a hot research topic.[19]
In this review, the properties and synthetic methodologies of IMNPs, their modified composites, and their applications to solve environmental challenges are summarized. These applications mainly focus on two aspects: (a) environmental analysis including the pretreatment of pollutants at trace levels before detection and selective preconcentration of target pollutants and (b) the detoxification, degradation and environmental remediation.

sections.heading: 2. Properties of iron-based magnetic nanomaterials
sections.text:
MNPs are made from materials that can be strongly attracted by magnets or can themselves be magnetized.[20,21] These materials include iron, nickel, cobalt, and alloys prepared from a mixture of magnetic metals and their oxides. Among these materials, iron and its oxides are widely used in the environmental field. Iron, a ferromagnetic material, possesses high magnetic susceptibility at room temperature and can be greatly magnetized even via a weak magnetic field. Iron oxides in nanoscale (usually Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 and usually <20 nm) are superparamagnetic materials and can be magnetized when exposed to an external applied low-intensity magnetic field. However, they exhibit no hysteresis in their magnetization curve and thus their magnetization immediately decreases to zero when the magnetic field is removed.[18,22,23]
In combination with an external magnetic field, IMNPs can be used to separate, extract, or purify contaminants from aqueous, gaseous, or muddy effluents. These IMNPs can then be regenerated by an appropriate elution or other approach.[10,24]
As far as separation is concerned, the advantage is that there is no need to centrifuge or filter the original sample, even if it is full of suspended solid materials. Therefore, phase separation is easily and quickly achieved after simply applying an external magnetic field.[25] Currently, IMNPs are very cheap and easily synthesized, making them useful for large-scale operations.The properties, such as size, shape, magnetism, dispersity, and chemical stability, of bare IMNPs are listed in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.1. Nanoscale zero-valent iron
sections.text: NZVI NPs possess several advantages over bulk or microscale iron materials, as their larger specific surface areas facilitate greater reaction rates, avoiding the formation of toxic byproducts generated from partial reactions.[26] They also consistently function as strong reductants and have been widely used for environmental remediation due to their environmentally benign property. They offer potent magnetic property, which is attributed to the fact that a-Fe has a very high saturation magnetization of 218 emu per g-Fe.[27] while, they exhibit a magically superparamagnetic property with size below 10–20 nm. However, extremely small and dispersive NZVI are known to be pyrophoric in air, which makes further applications be suppressed for a long time.[28]

2.3. Modified MNPs
While IMNPs have attracted much more attention due to their merits, pure IMNPs have some limitations in practical applications. Their strong magnetism leads to aggregation and causes side reactions during the chemical preparation process and when used in applications.[33,34] Aggregation is a critical drawback because it reduces the specific surface area and the interfacial free energy,[35] ultimately diminishing adsorption. The principal cause of aggregation is generally assumed to be short-range van der Waals attractive forces as well as remnant magnetization forces between the particles. The rate of aggregation increases with increased particle concentration and the increase of saturation magnetization (i.e., the maximum intrinsic magnet moment).[36] Therefore, special surface modification using other materials is of great importance.[37] Some soluble dispersants and organic/inorganic polymers are often used to mitigate agglomeration and enhance dispersibility in aqueous phase.[38,39] Currently, novel modifications are being studied to address these obstacles to improve the particles’ functionality.[15]
For instance, modifications may enhance the speed and efficiency of reactions, increase thermal/pH sensitivity and increase the availability of special integrated sites.[40–43] However, magnetism of modified IMNPs has been shown to significantly decrease in comparison to that of bare IMNPs in batch experiments. Wang et al.[44] compared the saturation magnetization of polydopamine-modified magnetite (Fe3O4@PDA) versus bare Fe3O4 NPs and obtained clear results (Figure 1) showing that PDA modification diminished the maximal saturation magnetization. This kind of modification would suppress the magnetic separation of MNPs and prolong the separation process.[45] Thus, it is very important to utilize a proper coating to maintain a useful magnetic separation effect. Some modified materials mentioned below are listed in Table 2. Both single-function (hydrophilic/hydrophobic) and bifunctional (amphiphilic or multicomplexing ends) inorganic or/and organic compounds can be used to modify the IMNPs.[18]
Modified IMNPs often retain both the beneficial features of their inorganic or organic components and, in addition, their properties can be systematically finetuned through their incorporation of appropriate functional components.[46]

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Carbon materials
sections.text:
Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are a kind of carbon nanomaterial, which can be used to support NZVIs in application. It will enhance the transportation, suspension, and stability of NZVIs. Deng et al. had successfully encapsulated NZVIs into the cavities of pea-pod–like CNTs.[52] Sun et al.[53] had fabricated NZVIs encapsulated in carbon sphere (Fe@CS) with degradation ability of phenol in solution. Recently graphene, a novel carbon material, was reported to modify of IMNPs (Fe3O4) successfully.
[25,54] Graphene has a special configuration consisting of a flat monolayer of sp2-bonded carbon atoms tightly packed into a two-dimensional honeycomb lattice, endowing it with ultra-high specific surface area (2630 m2 g¡1), superior chemical stability, excellent thermal stability and novel mechanical properties.[55–59] Based on its structure, graphene is hydrophobic with a strong affinity for carbon-based ring structures. As a result, its application in the modification of IMNPs has greatly contributed to the analysis and remediation of pollutants.[25] It has also been reported to have great potential in preconcentration of trace PAHs from environmental water samples through strong p-p stacking interactions.[60] Cao et al.[61] synthesized Fe3O4-grafted graphene for the determination of PCBs in water samples. Graphene oxide (GO), a chemical variant of graphene, has also attracted much attention in recent years.[58,62] It possesses large numbers of oxygen atoms on its surface in the form of epoxy, hydroxyl, and carboxyl groups. Because GO is much more hydrophilic than graphene, it has affinities toward a different range of compounds.[63] Han et al.[64]
reported their application of Fe3O4/GO toward removal of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons in wastewater treatment. A composite magnetic material consisting of zero-valent iron, iron oxide-oxyhydroxide, and graphene had been fabricated and successfully employed as adsorbent for enrichment of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), and phthalates.[65]

sections.heading: 2.3.4. Others
sections.text:
Clay minerals are natural two-dimensional nanomaterials. They are widely available, inexpensive, safe, and hydrophilic. From some reports, caly materials are metioned to be efficient adsorbents toward metal ions and some organic maters.[74]
When acting as supporting material, they can prevent NP aggregation, so as to avoid significant loss of reactivity. Kerkez et al.[75] had manufactured three clay supported NZVIs, bentonite, kaolin and native clay-supported NZVIs, for degradation of industrial azo dye Rosso Zetanyl B-NG. Interest in metal-organic framework (MOF) materials has grown due to their novel structures and functionalities. They are reported to possess extremely large surface areas, remarkably low density, and microporosity, and can easily be modified to have different pore sizes, making them promising candidates for storage, separation and catalysis.[76] Chen et al.[77]
optimized fabrication of Fe3O4@MOF NPs and used them as adsorbents for the enrichment of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs). Dopamine is a valuable substance which can self-polymerize under gentle conditions (aerobic and alkalescent) and is often used to fabricate polydopamine (PDA). PDA has good affinity for many organic pollutants due to its biocompatibility, dispersibility in water, multifunctional groups (amino and catechol groups), and ability to provide p-p stacking interactions with aromatic compounds. PDA-coated IMNPs are reported to have superior binding capacity for polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs).[44] Subsequently, much interest has been focused on the design of additional novel smart polymeric materials in recent years, resulting in smarter polymerics that can respond with shape and volume changes to small external stimuli such as temperature, pH, ionic strength, and magnetic fields.[78,79] Among these intelligent

sections.heading: 3. Synthetic methodology
sections.text: Various methods have been developed to synthesize MNPs, modify their surface properties, enhance their reactivity, and improve their field deployment and delivery. Herein, we discuss several common methods, and mainly focus on their mechanisms of action, rather than their synthetic processes. To date, several popular methods have been reported for synthesis of MNPs such as coprecipitation, microemulsion, thermal decomposition, solvothermal, sonochemical, chemical vapor deposition, combustion synthesis, carbon arc, and laser pyrolysis synthesis.[14] The traditional methods for bare IMNPs mentioned below are listed in Table 1.

However, these Fe NPs dispersed in hexane were quickly oxidized and/or agglomerated within 2 hr when the dispersion was exposed to air. Further study indicated the presence of a stable core-shell structure (of Fe/Fe3O4 NPs) in hexane or water dispersion. The particles synthesized by this method are always monodisperse, having small size and narrow size distribution and high crystallinity. However, it is generally expensive and require specific and costly equipment.
As the requirement of energy conservation, some researchers started looking for some natural or waste material for NPs’ manufacture. Mukherjee et al.[96] used the iron-rich waste sludge produced from steel mill as a substitute for other iron precursor reagent and used those NZVIs as reductants in heptachlor remediation. Machado et al.[97] developed a green approach to use extracts of leaf to take place of toxic borohydride. The abundant polyphenol acts as the functional reductant to reduce ferric iron.

As water-in-oil (W/O) microemulsion method is concerned, the reaction takes place at water nanodomain and spherical particles are formed with narrow size distribution.[104] The particles are highly dispersed attributing to the surfactants around them. Well-dispersed fine Fe3O4 NPs are also generated by thermal decomposition synthesis.[105,106] However, microemulsion and thermal decomposition methods are complicated compared to coprecipitation and solvothermal methods. Some properties of those Fe3O4 NPs prepared by different methods are listed in Table 1.
Greener manufacture protocols are also pursued in Fe3O4 NPs preparation. Ultrafine and superparamagnetic Fe3O4 NPs were first synthesized by modified coprecipitation method with soya bean sprouts templates under ambient temperature and normal atmosphere in Cai et al.’s research.[107] Wei and Viadero[32] had recovered ferric iron from acid mine drainage and used it as a precursor toprepare Fe3O4 NPs, which is a successful green method.
Magnetite IMNPs are easily oxidized into maghemite (g-Fe2O3) in the atmosphere. So the oxidation of magnetite is the most popular method to prepare pure maghemite (g-Fe2O3) NPs. Sun et al.
[108] synthesized the maghemite (g-Fe2O3) NPs using aeration to oxidize acidified magnetite NPs in an aqueous suspension. Hu et al.[109] fabricated g-Fe2O3 NPs by heating Fe3O4 NPs at 250 C in an air atmosphere for 2 hr. In addition, hydrolysis of iron salts is also an efficient method to fabricate well dispersed spindle Fe2O3 NPs in Varanda et al.’s research.
[110] It has been shown that magnetite is converted into maghemite (g-Fe2O3) in the presence of oxygen due to various electron or ion transfers depending upon the pH value. However, when Fe3O4 is the target material, oxidation should be avoided. To address this issue, protection from the acidic medium with the use of ferric nitrate should be considered.[111]

sections.heading: 4.1. Environmental analysis
sections.text:
Organic and inorganic pollutants have become increasingly prevalent in the environment in recent years. In order to address this issue, it is of great urgency that rapid, sensitive, and simple low-cost methods are developed to monitor actual environmental levels of pollutants. Because environmental matrices are very complex and the concentrations of the pollutants therein are very low, the sensitivities of currently used instruments are not sufficient to effectively analyze these pollutants directly.[112] Highly sensitive instruments require “clean samples before analysis. Thus, a pretreatment or preconcentration procedure is often necessary to develop highly selective, sensitive, accurate, and cost-effective detection results.[71]
The strong adsorptive ability of IMNPs, especially modified IMNPs, for many organic or inorganic compounds is crucial to methods development. Several determination works using IMNPs as adsorbents have been reported, as summarized in

Wang et al. prepared Fe3O4@polydopamine (Fe3O4@PDA) NPs and established a highly sensitive analytical method for trace detection of PAHs in water samples using MSPE coupled with HPLC–FLD.[44] The material exhibited excellent adsorption to selected PAHs at low levels, and the recoveries and detection limits were in range of 76.4– 107% and 0.51–1.92 ng l¡1, respectively. Compared with other Fe3O4-based nanosized adsorbents, Fe3O4@PDA was a superior adsorbent with high adsorption ability to PAHs.[44] In the same year, Ma et al.[125] investigated the enrichment potential of synthesized Fe3O4@PDA NPs for eleven small molecular pollutants (molecular weights from 251.6–499.3). All the functionalized structures (p¡p stacking, hydroxyl, amino, and catechol groups) show Fe3O4@PDA to be an excellent matrix for use in matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF-MS). Fe3O4@PDA MNPs were shown to be an efficient SPE adsorbent for trace levels of BaP in solution at 1 pg ml¡1 in 60 min. This method was facile, high-speed, and environmentally friendly.
Recently, a new combination of ionic liquid (IL) and methyl orange (MO) incorporated into the shells of MNPs was explored for the preconcentration of five PAHs, including Flu, AnT, Pyr, BaA, and BaP model analytes.[127] This material Fe3O4@IL@MO proved to be an excellent adsorbent for PAHs based on p–p interactions and hydrophobic interactions with the MO benzene rings and the hydrocarbon chains in the ILs. The LODs of Flu, AnT, Pyr, BaA, and BaP were 1, 0.1, 2, 0.8, and 0.4 ng l¡1, respectively. The recoveries for real water samples were in the range of 80.4–100.4% with RSDs in the range of 2.4–4.9%. This method effectively combined the high solubility of ILs in many organics with the p–p interactions between MO and compounds containing benzene rings, which will be a good starting point to develop effective methods for related pollutants.

Zhao et al.[171] used CTAB-coated Fe3O4 MNPs as adsorbents to enrich perfluorinated compounds (PFCs) in environmental samples. They used 50 mg adsorbents to extract the perfluorinated compounds from 800 mL environmental water samples, taking only 30 min to achieve acceptable analytical performance. The detection limits obtained for perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA), perfluorooctane sulfonic acid (PFOS), perfluorononanoic acid (PFNA), perfluorodecanoic acid (PFDA), perfluoroundecanoic acid (PFUnDA), perfluorododecanoic acid (PFDoDA), and perfluorotetradecanoic acid (PFTA) were 0.14, 0.022, 0.31, 0.23, 0.11, 0.16, and 0.091 ng l¡1, respectively. sections.heading: 4.2. Environmental remediation
sections.text:
Widespread pollution of soil and water is a serious problem for which environmental remediation is urgently needed. Environmental remediation usually involves degradation, sequestration, or other related approaches that result in removal of pollutants to lessen risks to human beings, animals and environmental reservoirs impacted by chemical and radiological contaminants.[131] The enormous adaptability of NPs gives them diverse opportunities to play a role in in situ environmental remediation.[14]
Because excavation is the highest capital cost for in situ remediation, many researchers have made significant strides to develop alternative means of cleanup by exploiting nanomaterials, which can be injected into contaminated slurry or groundwater.[26] Nanoparticles are extremely versatile remediation tools due to their small particle sizes (1–100 nm) and their ability to be anchored onto a solid matrix (e.g., activated carbon and/or zeolite).[40] The ability of IMNPs to remove pollution from an environmental medium is based on the mechanisms of adsorption and reduction, and some minor participation of catalysis by the attached

sections.heading: 4.2.2. The remediation of inorganic pollution
sections.text: In water and soil, inorganic pollutants such as radioactive elements (e.g., uranium), heavy metals (e.g., As, Hg), fluoride and phosphate are inevitably discharged into the environment. The applications of IMNPs on inorganic pollution remediation have been widely studied.

sections.heading: 4.2.2.1. NZVI-based IMNPs
sections.text:
Laboratory studies have demonstrated that NZVI can effectively transform a wide variety of environmental inorganic contaminants, including heavy metal ions (e.g., Ni2C, Hg2C, As5C, Cr6C), radioactive elements (e.g., uranium), and metalloids (e.g., nitrate or phosphate).[70,91,156–158] This procedure always contains two steps: first, the target matter must be adsorbed onto the NZVI’s surface, and, second, chemical reactions must occur to degrade those compounds to less harmful products.
Recognized as a human carcinogen, arsenic (As) is abundant in our environment originating from both natural and anthropogenic sources[159] and has been known to cause harmful effects to both human health and to the environment, even at low levels. The adsorption of arsenate using a magnetic separation technique is a useful method.[137] Kanel et al.[91] evaluated the removal efficiency of As(III) and observed that As(III) could be removed by adsorption onto ZVI NPs over a wide pH range (4–10) in a very short time (minutes). The maximum adsorption capacity of As (III) calculated from batch experiments was 3.5 mg g¡1 ZVI NPs. In the subsequent trials, this group gathered further evidence on the effective remediation of As(V) using ZVI NPs. By applying ZVI NPs at acidic and neutral pH values (pH 3–7) for groundwater treatment, a 100% removal of As(V) was accomplished by using 0.1, 0.2, and 0.4 g l¡1 ZVI NPs in only several minutes.[157] These two surveys confirmed that ZVI NPs were gradually converted into magnetite/maghemite corrosion products mixed with lepidocrocite over 60 and 90 days, respectively. The corrosion products also affected the adsorption of As. In real samples, larger amounts of ZVI NPs are required, due to the presence of competing anions.[91,157]
Boparai et al.[160] investigated the kinetics and thermodynamics of cadmium ion removal by adsorption onto NZVI particles. The process reached equilibrium after 30 min when the concentrations of NZVI and Cd2C were 0.5 g l¡1 and 112.5 mg l¡1, respectively. Although the increased temperature could improve the cadmium adsorption rate, the maximum adsorption capacity in different temperatures was similar, ranging from 213 to 225 mg g¡1 (285–333 K).[160] Hexavalent chromium is a also big threat to the environment. The reduction of Cr(VI) by NZVI and the adsorption by NZVI corrosion products endowed them with the ability to the remove Cr(VI) from aqueous solution. sections.heading: 5. Economic effects
sections.text:
IMNPs technology is a promising technology, facilitating green and sustainable economic growth.[187] For society, nanotechnology can support the creation of more jobs. For environmental application, more low cost and effieient functional materials, functioned as disinfectants, bacteriacides, reductants, catalysts, and adsorbents, are provided due to their valuable advantages over conventional approaches. They may not only alleviate the adverse effect caused from environmental pollution to economy, but also reduce the cost of restoration in comparison with some traditional treatment. While, this is still an emerging field, which means that most of the applications are remaining in investigation stage, lacking in sufficient cost-benefit analysis. Herein, only the implementation of NZVI technology in in situ remediation of contaminated water or soil is achieved. NZVI could provide cost-effective solutions to some of the most challenging environmental cleanup problems, like organochlorine pesticides contaminant.[40] When compared to in situ chemical oxidation applications, NZVI injections are cost competitive from field-scale demonstrations.[188] For another instance, NZVIs, substituting pump and treat in wastewater treatment, exhibit 25–30 times faster reaction rates and result in a net present value of £2.4 billion to UK economy in total 20 years.[187] Gavaskar et al.[189] estimated the economic present value of the pump-and-treat costs over 30 years to be $1,365,000, and an equivalent treatment cost of the emulsified ZVI treatment was $452,000. The market for drink water purification and wastewater disposal is estimated to reach $6.6 billion by 2015, up from $1.6 billion in 2007.[187] And it is said that NZVI’s degradation capabilities may be maximized when used at injection points where contamination levels are at their highest.[188]
Aside from those benefit obtained from pollution treatment, IMNPs synthesized from green raw materials also produce a beneficial effect, such as the NZVI made from steel pickling waste liquor and Fe3O4 made from acid mine drainage and natural reductant: a kind of root extract.[32,190,191]
Although IMNPs used in environmental field opens a promising prospect in economic growth, its development takes more time than previously anticipated as there is always a great distance from laboratory to the market. Meanwhile, the generation and treatment of so-called nanowaste is also a point to be paid more attention.

With the concomitant development of superior surface coating materials, IMNPs could be customized to excel at specific functions, opening up new avenues for use in multipurpose applications. However, several existing problems concerning these unique materials must first be solved: (a) how to optimize and simplify the IMNP preparation methods and modification processes and minimize their production costs; (b) how to use reasonable modifications to enhance IMNP properties to avoid destruction or aggregation; (c) how to minimize the environmental risks resulting from the release of IMNPs to the environment, among others; and (d) the economical effect should be evaluated when introducing IMNPs to practical application in environmental field. Once these issues are addressed, improved IMNPs hold great promise to help us face the complex environmental challenges that will undoubtedly unfold with increasing global population growth and industrialization in the future.

metadata.abstractText: In recent years, many novel nanomaterials with distinct structures have emerged as a result of intense research efforts by many groups. Among them, iron-based magnetic nanomaterials, which exhibit special physical and chemical properties, have been successfully adapted to many applications in a wide range of fields including catalysis, biotechnology, biomedicine, magnetic resonance imaging, data storage, biosensors, and removal of environmental pollutants, among others. Because of their low cost, ease of manufacture, and ease of modification, they have great potential for environmental analysis and remediation of a wide range of organic and inorganic pollutants. In order to enhance understanding and develop better methods for their use in environmental applications, this review focuses on the properties, synthesis methods, and environmental applications for iron-based magnetic nanomaterials such as nanoscale zero-valent iron, magnetite (Fe3O4), maghemite (g-Fe2O3), and their functionalized composites.
